entry.title: Coronavirus: Can Russia flatten the curve?

media:group.media:title: Coronavirus: Can Russia flatten the curve?
media:group.media:description:
Russia is now among the ten nations most affected by coronavirus, with Moscow announcing on Monday that recorded cases had reached 87,147.
Russia, like most countries dealing with the pandemic, faces a list of hurdles in flattening the curve. Medical staff in Moscow say they don‚Äôt have enough personal protective gear and point to a high rate of infection among health workers.
The government has also moved to combat misinformation around the virus, taking measures including launching a smartphone app that tracks people who are under quarantine. Government opponents call the measures draconian and have said they risk turning Russia into a "digital concentration camp". In this episode of The Stream, we discuss Russia‚Äôs handling of the pandemic, and ask is there anything more that can be done.

#Aljazeeraenglish #News #AJStream

entry.title: Why is worldwide military spending going up? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Why is worldwide military spending going up? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
It's often said that war is good for business. Conflicts drive up demand for weapons, defence equipment and soldiers. It appears last year was a bumper year. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute says global military spending grew to nearly two trillion dollars, a 3.6 percent increase on 2018 and the highest level rise in 10 years. Five countries - the US, China, India, Russia and Saudi Arabia - account for more than 60 percent of the expenditure. Will the upward trend continue as the coronavirus pandemic devastates the world's economies?
Presneter: Bernard Smith
Guests: Pieter Wezeman - Senior Researcher of the Arms and Military Expenditure Programme at the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute
Adam Ni - Director of the Australia-based China Policy Centre
Andrew Smith - Spokesman for the Campaign Against Arms Trade

entry.title: El Salvador prisons: President authorises use of lethal force

media:group.media:title: El Salvador prisons: President authorises use of lethal force
media:group.media:description:
El Salvador security officials have been authorised to use ‚Äúlethal force‚Äù against gang members following a surge in violence during the pandemic. A state of emergency has been imposed in prisons, with inmates now locked in their overcrowded cells all day. Al Jazeera's Laura Burdon-Manley reports.

entry.title: üá∫üá∏ Why are black Americans hardest hit by coronavirus? | The Stream

media:group.media:title: üá∫üá∏ Why are black Americans hardest hit by coronavirus? | The Stream
media:group.media:description:
The number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the United States has now passed 977,000, with the death toll in the tens of thousands. But the disease is disproportionately affecting black Americans. Recent official figures in Louisiana show that African Americans account for 56 percent of those who have died from COVID-19 but only 32 percent of the general population.
Health researchers, journalists and social scientists say there are several reasons why black Americans are especially impacted by coronavirus - such as the essential public-facing jobs they often hold and the under-served areas in which many live. Racial justice advocates say the challenges that coronavirus poses to black communities in the US stem from decades of racist public policy and stereotyping.
The Stream will look at how coronavirus is a life-or-death issue for black Americans.
Join the conversation: TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
#coronavirus #ajstream #aljazeeraenglish #racism

entry.title: China's unity song backfires as propaganda on South China Sea

media:group.media:title: China's unity song backfires as propaganda on South China Sea
media:group.media:description:
A song released by China to highlight its partnership with the Philippines against the COVID-19 outbreak is being criticised as propaganda. It has been "disliked" more than 100,000 times on YouTube. Many Filipinos found the lyrics a thinly veiled attempt by Beijing to reassert its claims over the disputed South China Sea. Al Jazeera's Jamela Alindogan reports.

entry.title: Lebanon protests: Central bank criticised as currency plummets

media:group.media:title: Lebanon protests: Central bank criticised as currency plummets
media:group.media:description:
Protesters in Lebanon have been defying a lockdown and curfew to continue anti-government protests. Demonstrators blocked roads and fought with police while denouncing the worsening economic crisis. Last week, Lebanon's currency reached new lows against the dollar - sparking calls for the central bank governor to resign. Al Jazeera's Zeina Khodr reports from Beirut, Lebanon.

entry.title: NY Grieves: Inside the COVID-19 Pandemic | Between Us

media:group.media:title: NY Grieves: Inside the COVID-19 Pandemic | Between Us
media:group.media:description:
New York is the epicentre of the coronavirus outbreak in the United States. Millions of people have been impacted.
Covering it ‚Äúhas been hell‚Äù as Al Jazeera correspondent Gabriel Elizondo shares in our latest episode of Between Us. - Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: UK PM warns of risking second coronavirus wave

media:group.media:title: UK PM warns of risking second coronavirus wave
media:group.media:description:
Britain's Prime Minister has returned to work vowing to lead from the front in the fight against coronavirus. Boris Johnson was diagnosed with the virus a month ago and spent three days in Intensive care. In his first speech since leaving hospital, he says the UK's starting to turn the tide in tackling the outbreak. Johnson has pledged his government will outline plans for easing restrictions but warns of the risk of a second wave.

entry.title: Pakistan: Once used by Taliban, Swat FM 98 now fights coronavirus

media:group.media:title: Pakistan: Once used by Taliban, Swat FM 98 now fights coronavirus
media:group.media:description:
Pakhtunkhwa Radio FM 98 in northern Pakistan is holding on-air clinics to help provide healthcare information to residents in remote areas. Once used by Taliban to spread propaganda and intimidate people in the Swat Valley, the radio waves are now used to educate the public about the coronavirus pandemic.
Al Jazeera's Alexi O'Brien reports.

entry.title: Food allergies: New findings on gut bacteria link in babies

media:group.media:title: Food allergies: New findings on gut bacteria link in babies
media:group.media:description:
Discovering your child has a food allergy can be a frightening experience. Researchers in Australia think they have now found a link between the chances of babies developing a reaction to the bacteria found in their mothers' stomach.
Al Jazeera's Sara Khairat reports.

entry.title: Coronavirus and farming: California farmworkers at high risk

media:group.media:title: Coronavirus and farming: California farmworkers at high risk
media:group.media:description:
The United States depends on millions of farmworkers to maintain its food supply. But cramped working and living conditions are putting them at increased risk of infection from COVID-19.
Al Jazeera's Rob Reynolds reports from Oxnard in California, the country's biggest agricultural producer.

#UScoronavirus #COVID19 #FarmWorkers

entry.title: Ecuador woman learns sister is alive after cremating wrong body

media:group.media:title: Ecuador woman learns sister is alive after cremating wrong body
media:group.media:description:
Health workers in Ecuador have apologised for telling a woman her sister had died of the coronavirus, only to find out she was alive and recovering in a hospital. Ecuador's number of confirmed cases has almost doubled over just two days. And the strain on the health system has begun to show in disturbing ways.
Al Jazeera's Lucia Newman reports.

#Coronavirus #Ecuador #AljazeeraEnglish

entry.title: Saudi-led coalition rejects south Yemen self-rule declaration

media:group.media:title: Saudi-led coalition rejects south Yemen self-rule declaration
media:group.media:description:
The Saudi-led coalition in Yemen is calling for an end to violence after southern separatists in the city of Aden declared self-rule. The Southern Transitional Council which the UAE backs is seeking a return to independence and is accusing the government of mismanagement. But Saudi Arabia is calling for all sides to abide by a power-sharing agreement signed five months ago.
Al Jazeera‚Äôs Dorsa Jabbari reports.

#Yemen #YemenWar #SouthernYemen

entry.title: Spanish children allowed outside for first time in six weeks

media:group.media:title: Spanish children allowed outside for first time in six weeks
media:group.media:description:
Spain has recorded its lowest daily death toll from COVID-19 in more than a month. From Sunday, as part of plans to ease restrictions on the public, children under the age of 14 have been allowed to go out for one hour a day.
Al Jazeera's Nadim Baba reports.

#EuropeCoronavirus #Coronavirus #Spain

entry.title: More US states set to ease coronavirus lockdown measures

media:group.media:title: More US states set to ease coronavirus lockdown measures
media:group.media:description:
More US states are loosening lockdown measures as the death toll in the country passes 54,000 and health officials say more testing and contact tracing are needed. Colorado, Mississippi, Minnesota, Montana and Tennessee will join the first group of states as the US's jobless rate rises to 16 percent or higher. The White House official coordinating the response to the coronavirus outbreak says social distancing may be necessary through the northern summer.
Al Jazeera‚Äôs Heidi Zhou-Castro reports Washington, DC, the United States.

#UScoronavirus #COVID19 #ReopenAmerica
